extracted-table.table-caption: A summary of the multimodal MRI to assess leukoaraiosis with cognitive impairment.

caption.p: A summary of the multimodal MRI to assess leukoaraiosis with cognitive impairment.

tr.td: Gray-matter atrophy, white-matter lesions, and whole-brain atrophy
Decreased gray-matter density in frontal lobes, hippocampus, and cingulate cortex;lower cortical thickness in multimodal integration regions, such as frontotemporal regions
Identify the intrinsic spontaneous brain neural activity during resting state to investigate the brain function, such as amplitude of low-frequency fluctuations (ALFF) and default-mode network (DMN)

Significant decrease in ALFF in the left parahippocampal gyrus (PHG) and an increased ALFF in right superior orbital frontal gyrus (SOFG);increased functional connectivity (FC) between the right insular region and the right SOFG and between the right calcarine cortex and the left PHG;significant differences in functional alterations of the DMN
Impaired CVR may contribute to the progression of white matter disease
Determine the integrity and lesions of white-matter tracts, such as fractional anisotropy (FA) and mean diffusivity (MD)
Dysfunction of white matter integrity;DTI parameters (especially FA) could serve as a potent imaging indicator for detecting the invisible alteration of white matter integrity
Evaluate the permeability and integrity of blood-brain barrier (BBB); quantitative tissue perfusion such as blood volume, mean transit time, mean transit time
Higher BBB permeability was associated with higher LA burden and cognitive decline
Identify changes in cerebral metabolites such as the ratios of N-acetyl aspartate (NAA)/choline (Cho) and NAA/creatine (Cr)
Metabolic changes suggested that MRS can be explored as a marker for cognitive dysfunction in patients with LA

extracted-table.transformed-table:
Table 1
A summary of the multimodal MRI to assess leukoaraiosis with cognitive impairment.
Multimodal MRI techniquesMain observation targetsThe main findings
1Structural Magnetic Resonance Imaging (sMRI)Gray-matter atrophy, white-matter lesions, and whole-brain atrophyDecreased gray-matter density in frontal lobes, hippocampus, and cingulate cortex;lower cortical thickness in multimodal integration regions, such as frontotemporal regions
2Blood oxygen level-dependent (BOLD) contrastIdentify the intrinsic spontaneous brain neural activity during resting state to investigate the brain function, such as amplitude of low-frequency fluctuations (ALFF) and default-mode network (DMN)Significant decrease in ALFF in the left parahippocampal gyrus (PHG) and an increased ALFF in right superior orbital frontal gyrus (SOFG);increased functional connectivity (FC) between the right insular region and the right SOFG and between the right calcarine cortex and the left PHG;significant differences in functional alterations of the DMN
3Cerebrovascular reactivity (CVR) measurementsCerebral autoregulation and vasodilatory capacityImpaired CVR may contribute to the progression of white matter disease
4Diffusion tensor imaging (DTI)Determine the integrity and lesions of white-matter tracts, such as fractional anisotropy (FA) and mean diffusivity (MD)Dysfunction of white matter integrity;DTI parameters (especially FA) could serve as a potent imaging indicator for detecting the invisible alteration of white matter integrity
5Dynamic contrast enhancement (DCE) MRIEvaluate the permeability and integrity of blood-brain barrier (BBB); quantitative tissue perfusion such as blood volume, mean transit time, mean transit timeHigher BBB permeability was associated with higher LA burden and cognitive decline
6Magnetic resonance spectroscopy (MRS)Identify changes in cerebral metabolites such as the ratios of N-acetyl aspartate (NAA)/choline (Cho) and NAA/creatine (Cr)Metabolic changes suggested that MRS can be explored as a marker for cognitive dysfunction in patients with LA
